answers.answer: Is your AFib permanent, or rare/intermittent?  If the latter a simple aspirin may be an alternative to coumadin - but if the AFib is there all or frequently a blood anticoagulant such as coumadin may be necessary.  I have never had a problem with taking coumadin, of course while running some risk of bleeding. I was able to jog for exercise up to age 67 and was on coumadin for years by that time (I take the generic warfarin).I'm not sue what the Carvedilol is, but assume it is a beta blocker.  Some of us are lucky and are converted out of AFib by taking a BB.  It is worth a try in my "book".Many, maybe most of us over 60, have some heart valve regurgitation (leakage) but if it doesn't cause heart artium enlargement and we are not short of breath, then we can just live with it I think.I could be worth you time and money to discuss you goals with your current doctor.  He may agree on taking an aspirin rather than coumadin.

question: A few weeks ago, I was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  2 ECGs were done.1 Echocardiogram.  I am 62 and very healthy.  I do not take any medication.  I have an A in my annual physical check up.  No hypotension, no diabetes.In the Echocardiogram report show a mild to moderate tricuspid valvular regurgitation and the cardiologist wanted to prescribe me Coumadin and Carvedilol capsule and wanted me to start taking them while in the hospital.  I told him I'm not psychologically, emotionally and physically ready for it and I need a few days to think about it.  Since all my blood tests, ECG results are all normal except the TVR.  What would you suggest in terms of taking the medication or should I go see an electro physiciologist?  Thank you.
title: Medication and Mild tricuspid valvular regurgitation.
